If XXX is an affine algebraic variety (or just an affine scheme of finite type) over a field KKK, and if OX(X)=A\mathcal{O}_X(X)=AOX​(X)=A, and if RRR is a commutative KKK-algebra with a topology making RRR into a topological ring, then I imagine that the RRR-points X(R)X(R)X(R) (i.e. the KKK-algebra homomorphisms from AAA to RRR) inherit a canonical topology; for example one can write down a closed immersion from XXX into some large affine space AN\mathbb{A}^NAN and this identifies X(R)X(R)X(R) with a subspace of RNR^NRN, so we can give it the subspace topology. My instinct is that this topology is independent of the choice of closed immersion but I just spent a few minutes writing down what I thought would be the proof (given two embeddings into RNR^NRN and RMR^MRM consider the product embedding and then look at projections) and couldn't immediately finish it off. What trick am I missing?

Now say XXX is also smooth, and KKK is a nontrivially normed field. Then do the same sort of ideas give X(K)X(K)X(K) the structure of a manifold over KKK, again independent of all choices? Smoothness is some criterion about differentials behaving which will be enough to make things like the implicit function theorem kick in, and then I get stuck at the same point as above.

The internet seems to be full of people saying that all of this is obvious. How hard will it be to formalise? I need it for FLT :-)
oh you don't need to embed anything. Just take the coarsest topology making the algebraic functions continuous.
you could formalize the topology as some infimum of some induced topologies, etc.
as for smoothness and the manifold structure, that's of course a much bigger deal.

I think that the coarsest topology making everything continuous is embedding it into affine A-space :-) So then the question becomes: is it true that this is the subspace topology for a closed embedding? Concretely, if my affine variety is GL_n and the topological ring is the reals, how do I prove that the topology you're suggesting agrees with the two topologies I've seen in the literature, namely those obtained by embedding into R^{n^2+1} via mapping M to (M,1/det(M)) and by embedding into R^{2n^2} via (M,1/M)?
but the point is that you don't even need to assume that it's affine.

If XXX is any variety over KKK, and UUU is Zariski open, then f∈O(U)f \in \mathcal{O}(U)f∈O(U) induces U(K)→KU(K) \to KU(K)→K. Now take the induced topology with respect to this map on U(K)U(K)U(K) and take the infimum as all fff vary. Now look at the coinduced topology on X(K)X(K)X(K), then take the supermum of all such as UUU varies.
I think that should work.

I think it's also possible to characterize this as the coarsest family of topologies on X(K)X(K)X(K) as XXX vary over all KKK-varieties for which all f∈O(X)f \in \mathcal{O}(X)f∈O(X) induce continuous map X(K)→KX(K) \to KX(K)→K and for which X→YX \to YX→Y induce continuous maps X(K)→Y(K)X(K) \to Y(K)X(K)→Y(K) for any morphism of varieties

I guess the condition on X(K)→KX(K) \to KX(K)→K is superfluous since you can just look at morphisms X→A1X \to \mathbb{A}^1X→A1 (once you identify the topology on A1(K)=K\mathbb{A}^1(K) = KA1(K)=K with the strong one) :)

Right but you're not answering the question. I don't doubt that your idea is a good idea but what I'm saying is that in the special case of GL_n(R) this is not how the topology is defined in the literature.

If XXX is affine, I believe the topology you describe is indeed independent of the choice of closed immersion.

Let X→ANX \to \mathbb{A}^NX→AN be a closed immersion and let f1,…,fN∈O(X)f_1, \ldots, f_N \in \mathcal{O}(X)f1​,…,fN​∈O(X) be the NNN coordinate functions. The topology you describe is the coarsest topology such that for all iii, the evaluation X(R)→RX(R) \to RX(R)→R of fif_ifi​ is continuous. Since f1,…,fNf_1, \ldots, f_Nf1​,…,fN​ generate O(X)\mathcal{O}(X)O(X), this is equivalent to the statement that the evaluation X(R)→RX(R) \to RX(R)→R of fff is continuous for all f∈O(X)f \in \mathcal{O}(X)f∈O(X).
Right. You would have to show that polynomial functions are continuous for that proof. Do we have that?
docs#MvPolynomial.continuous_eval

In fact, I suspect that if we put a topology on X(R)X(R)X(R) using the method Adam Topaz describes, then:

  1. If X→YX \to YX→Y is a closed immersion, then X(R)→Y(R)X(R) \to Y(R)X(R)→Y(R) is a closed embedding.
  2. (X×Y)(R)=X(R)×Y(R)(X \times Y)(R) = X(R) \times Y(R)(X×Y)(R)=X(R)×Y(R) has the product topology.
And then, one more fact is needed to deduce the theorem you want, which is that the topology on A1(R)=R\mathbb{A}^1(R) = RA1(R)=R is the same as the original one that you put on RRR.

For the manifold question, here is the "low-powered" way. Suppose you have two closed immersions X→AmX \to \mathbb{A}^mX→Am and X→AnX \to \mathbb{A}^nX→An. We wish to show that the corresponding closed immersions f ⁣:X(K)→Kmf \colon X(K) \to K^mf:X(K)→Km and g ⁣:X(K)→Kng \colon X(K) \to K^ng:X(K)→Kn induce the same analytic manifold structure on X(K)X(K)X(K).

For any x∈X(K)x \in X(K)x∈X(K), one can construct an analytic function h ⁣:U→Knh \colon U \to K^nh:U→Kn, defined on a neighborhood UUU of f(x)f(x)f(x) in KmK^mKm, such that h(f(y))=g(y)h(f(y)) = g(y)h(f(y))=g(y) for yyy near xxx. (One can construct hhh by composing ggg with a function that is locally a left inverse of fff. This exists by the implicit function theorem.) So the identity function id⁡X(K)\operatorname{id}_{X(K)}idX(K)​ is locally analytic at xxx, where the manifold structure on the domain is induced by fff and the manifold structure on the codomain is induced by ggg. You can do the same in the reverse direction.
Hopefully I have not misunderstood what is going on here.
This makes me think that there should be an analogous low-level argument to show that any two closed immersions X -> A^n should induce the same topology on X(R).

Now that I think about this argument, maybe it needs a little more work.

I am referring to the work required to prove that hhh is actually analytic. I think you can't just say "it's analytic because it's the composition of two analytic functions", because that would be circular reasoning.
Even if this works, I'm not convinced there's an analogous argument for the topology on X(R)X(R)X(R). This seems to intrinsically rely on the implicit function theorem.

Kevin Buzzard said:

This makes me think that there should be an analogous low-level argument to show that any two closed immersions X -> A^n should induce the same topology on X(R).

Take the diagonal embedding in A^m x A^n. Taking the induced topologies of the product topology of R gives you 3 topologies on X, say T1 T2 and T. The maps from (X,T) to (X,T1) and (X,T2) are continuous since they just forget about coordinates, and one needs to show that they are homeomorphisms. Now, by definition of a closed immersion (Nullstellensatz), the second embedding of X to A^n factors through a map A^m -> A^n. Consequently, (X,T1)->(X,T) is of the form (x1,...,xm) -> (x1,...,xm, f1(x1,..,xm),...,fn(x1,...,xm)) where f1,..., fn are polynomials, and it follows from the definition of a topological ring that they induce continuous functions R^m ->R.
I didn't realize that you could just factor the map algebraically. That also gives a cleaner proof that the analytic structure is preserved.
